titles.title: Jaime Zapata and Victor Avila Federal Officers and Employees Protection Act

Jaime Zapata and Victor Avila Federal Officers and Employees Protection Act
Jaime Zapata and Victor Avila Federal Officers and Employees Protection Act
Jaime Zapata and Victor Avila Federal Officers and Employees Protection Act
A bill to amend title 18, United States Code, to further protect officers and employees of the United States, and for other purposes.

action.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Committee on the Judiciary. Ordered to be reported with an amendment in the nature of a substitute favorably.
Committee on the Judiciary. Reported by Senator Durbin with an amendment in the nature of a substitute. Without written report.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 61.

vote.text: Passed Senate with an amendment by Unanimous Consent.

reference.label: text of amendment in the nature of a substitute

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Ms. Jackson Lee moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 921.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

term.name: Government employee pay, benefits, personnel management

bill.summary:
Jaime Zapata and Victor Avila Federal Officers and Employees Protection Act
This bill explicitly grants extraterritorial jurisdiction over the following criminal offenses:
killing (or attempting to kill) a federal officer or employee; assaulting, kidnapping, or murdering (or threatening to do so, or attempting to kidnap or murder) a family member of certain federal officials to retaliate against or to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the federal official; threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder certain federal officials to retaliate against or to impede, intimidate, or interfere with the federal official; and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees. The United States may prosecute such conduct that occurs outside the United States.
